1_3_criteria: The group manager carried out socio-environmental assessments of the farms before they were included in the group, from which improvements to be implemented were identified. Improvements are monitored in annual internal audits. Only one of the audited farms presented non-conformities in items 1.3.1, 1.3.2 and 1.3.3, due to the lack of initial socio-environmental assessment.
2_1_criteria: In none of the audited farms is there evidence of forced labor, imposed , forced, trafficked or involuntary. There is no retention of documents, salaries or employee benefits. Family members of employees who live on farms are not required to work on the properties. There are no children under 15 working on the properties. Through interviews with employees, it was evident that there was no evidence of discrimination of any kind. Verified through employee payment slips, that there is no salary distinction for operators performing the same functions. Training, benefits and promotion opportunities are provided equally among employees. There is also no evidence of punishment, coercion or aggression of any kind on the audited farms.
2_2_criteria: All workers are registered. The farms have Employment Contracts with employees, describing all pertinent information. Workers receive instructions on how to carry out their activities safely at the time of hiring or through integration training.
2_3_criteria: All farms have a PPRA/PCMSO or PGSSMATR, where health and safety risks are identified, as well as mitigation and control measures. Workers demonstrated in interviews their knowledge and understanding of issues related to health and safety. Workers health is monitored through periodic medical examinations. On most of the farms audited, dangerous tasks are carried out only by qualified and trained personnel, with the exception of one of the farms where the pesticide applicator did not have training to carry out the activity, as determined by NR31. Farms provide PPE to their workers and delivery is recorded by most farms. Only one of the farms audited did not record the supply of PPE, which led to non-compliance in item 2.3.4. The use of PPE and compliance with safety requirements by workers is supervised and in case of non-compliance, Warning Notices are applied. Most farms have procedures in place for accidents and emergencies, and they are visible to workers. However, on one of the farms audited, it was verified through an interview that the procedures to be followed in case of accidents and emergencies are not clearly understood by all workers, which led to non-compliance in indicator 2.3.6. All farms have first aid kits and vehicles available for transportation. collectives, despite none of the farms audited having collective agreements with unions. Terminations of employment contracts are approved by the unions.
2_4_criteria: Interviews on all the farms revealed that workers are free to join trade unions of their choice and take part in collective bargaining negotiations, although none of the farms audited had collective bargaining agreements with unions. Employment contract terminations are approved by the unions.
2_5_criteria: On all farms audited, wages paid respect the national minimum wage. Verified payment receipts demonstrate that only deductions provided for by law are applied to farm employee payments, such as INSS and income tax. Salaries are paid by the fifth working day of the month and payment receipts are filed by the farms. The working day on farms is 44 hours per week, with occasional overtime, especially during harvest times, which does not exceed 10 hours per week. The hours worked are recorded on a time card on all farms, however, on one of the audited farms it was found that the hours worked on Sundays and holidays by some workers were not included in the time cards, just as on another farm it was found that overtime were not registered, which led to non-compliance in indicator 2.5.5 on both farms. Workers on all farms reported that overtime is voluntary. On most farms, overtime is paid, but as on one of the farms no records were kept, it was also not possible to verify whether they were paid appropriately, which led to non-compliance in indicator 2.5.6. On one of the farms it was also found that in some periods the cook worked more than six consecutive days without a day of rest, which led to non-compliance in indicator 2.5.6. On none of the farms audited were there any cases of workers taking maternity leave, but employers demonstrate that they are aware of their right to maternity leave. Housing for farm employees is adequate and has adequate sanitary conditions. Access to drinking water is guaranteed by the farms.
3_1_criteria: Communication channels with the farms include telephone, email and suggestion boxes available at their headquarters. The properties have signs at the entrances, informing the telephone numbers of the farms or producers. Verified through interviews that the communication channels are known and allow adequate communication between producers and local communities.
3_2_criteria: There are no cases of disputes regarding the rights to use the properties lands, as well as there is no evidence of existence of traditional users of the properties lands.
3_3_criteria: The farms have suggestion/complaint boxes at their headquarters, and any complaints are recorded on a form on most farms. Only on one of the audited farms was it not possible to demonstrate that complaints/complaints would be registered, which led to non-compliance in indicators 3.3.2 and 3.3.3. Also on another farm, the commitment to dealing with any complaints or grievances received in an appropriate and timely manner was not clear, leading to non-compliance in indicator 3.3.3.
3_4_criteria: Employment opportunities on the farms are always offered preferably to the local community, being publicized internally or on the municipalitys SINE. Some of the farms audited provide facilities and machinery for SENAR to carry out training. Only on two of the farms audited is there no collaboration with training programs aimed at the local population, which led to non-conformities in indicator 3.4.2.
4_1_criteria: The farms have a Socio-Environmental Diagnosis developed by the manager. Only one of the audited farms, which was recently included in the group, does not have the diagnosis, which led to non-compliance in items 4.1.1, 4.1.2, 4.1.3, 4.1.4 and 4.1.5.
4_2_criteria: No fires are carried out on any of the audited farms. Most of the waste is properly disposed of by the farms, however non-conformities were identified in two of the farms audited. Non-conformities in item 4.2.2 were identified due to used oil being used to maintain fences on one of the properties; fluorescent lamps are not separated into two properties; batteries are buried alongside common trash on one of the properties. Non-conformities were also identified in item 4.2.4 as the two farms bury non-biological waste on the properties. On one of the farms there is no suitable lane for washing machines, which led to non-compliance in indicator 4.2.3. On another farm, a non-compliance with indicator 4.2.5 was identified as there was no documented Waste Management Plan. All farms have a fuel tank with containment dam, channels and separator boxes. The properties houses have septic tanks.
4_3_criteria: Only one of the audited farms does not record the use of fossil fuels, leading to non-compliance in indicator 4.3.1. All farms monitor the organic matter content by carrying out soil analyses. Properties adopt practices that contribute to increasing soil carbon sequestration, such as: adoption of crop-livestock integration systems, cultivation of soil cover species, direct planting and maintenance of native vegetation.
4_4_criteria: In none of the audited farms were recent area openings made. All were made before 2008, as verified by satellite images comparing the areas in 2008 and 2017.
4_5_criteria: The property maps indicate native vegetation, production areas and watercourses. An Ecosystem and Wildlife Conservation Program is being implemented on all farms. From the comparative maps of areas in 2008 and 2017, it is possible to identify that native vegetation has been maintained on all properties. The properties prohibit hunting activities, and no logging or any other extraction is carried out native product. All audited farms have above 10% native vegetation.
5_1_criteria: The farms adopt good agricultural practices that prevent damage to water bodies, such as: use of correctives and fertilizers only in accordance with the technical recommendations; cultivation of species for mulching, such as millet, sunn hemp and brachiaria; adoption of the direct planting system; construction of contour lines in slope areas. In four of the farms audited, no analyzes are carried out to monitor water quality, which led to non-conformities in indicator 5.1.2. None of the farms audited use irrigation.
5_2_criteria: The farms identify on maps the location of watercourses, as well as the status of riparian vegetation. Farms that have degraded APP are implementing a Degraded Area Recovery Plan.
5_3_criteria: Soil quality monitoring is done through visual analyzes and analyzes carried out in the laboratory. Soil quality is preserved through the adoption of practices such as: adoption of the direct planting system; use of fertilizers and correctives in accordance with technical recommendations; cultivation of species for mulching, such as millet and sunn hemp. In sloping areas, farms build contour lines as a way to minimize erosion processes. Farms carry out succession of crops. There is no cultivation of soybeans on soybeans, the sanitary void period of the state in which the farms are located is respected.
5_4_criteria: The farms have a MIC Â– Integrated Crop Management plan, addressing the use of preventive methods and control that cause less environmental impact. Farms provide for the reduction of potentially harmful agrochemicals in a documented plan. Non-conformities were identified in indicator 5.4.5 on four of the farms audited, due to the lack of monitoring records for insect pests, diseases, weeds and natural enemies. The farms only use agrochemicals permitted for soybean cultivation and in the dosages prescribed by the technicians responsible, as evidenced in the deposits and records of agrochemical use.
5_5_criteria: All audited farms record the use of pesticides, however in On two farms the records do not include the names of the dosers/applicators, the identification of the application equipment used, nor the weather conditions during applications, which led to non-conformities in indicator 5.5.1. On all farms, empty packaging is washed at the time of application and delivered to reception centers. Most farms have empty packaging storage in accordance with regulations, closed, locked, fenced with mesh and covered. However, one of the farms did not have a warehouse and the empty packaging was stored in big bags until delivery to the receiving units, which led to non-compliance in indicator 5.5.2. All farms have agrochemical deposits and most are in compliance with standards, covered, closed, locked, signposted, with floors, emergency showers and eyewash stations. However, on one of the farms audited, the deposit does not have channels or a containment box. On the same farm, contaminated PPE is washed in the accommodation laundry by the employees themselves. Both situations led to non-compliance in indicator 5.5.3. On all audited farms, areas treated with pesticides are demarcated with signposts. Recommendations for the use of amendments and fertilizers are made by agronomists based on the results of soil analyses.
5_6_criteria: The farms do not use any agrochemicals listed in the Stockholm and Rotterdam Conventions. Some farms still use Paraquat, but it is already planned to gradually reduce its use by 2020, and it is no longer being purchased.
5_7_criteria: Not all farms use biological control agents, but they demonstrate knowledge about use of the same.
5_8_criteria: If an outbreak of new pests occurs, farms resort to institutions such as EMBRAPA, FAMATO, INDEA and the Rural Union.
5_9_criteria: Measures implemented by farms to prevent drift include monitoring weather conditions during applications, only carrying them out under suitable conditions, in addition to the use of correctly calibrated spraying equipment. Critical areas such as water bodies and residential areas are also observed. One of the farms presented non-compliance in item 5.9.2 for not recording the observed climatic conditions. On another farm, it was found that land applications of pesticides are carried out at distances less than 30 meters from residences, which led to non-conformity in indicator 5.9.5.
5_10_criteria: The production systems adopted by the farms are similar to neighbor systems. None of the farms have sensitive crops close to them, such as organic farming or Non-GMO soybeans. There is no history of damage to neighboring areas caused by drift from the audited properties.
5_11_criteria: None of the farms produce their own seeds. They all acquire from legally known sources, as verified in purchase invoices.

Name: Amaggi Commodities EU RED
1_1_criteria: The producer demonstrated knowledge of applicable laws and remains up to date with external advice from companies and technical professionals. Compliance with the laws was verified.
1_2_criteria: The right to use the land was evidenced through the registrations of the farm areas.
1_3_criteria: The group manager carried out a socio-environmental assessment of the farm before itself be included in the group, and from this the aspects to be improved were identified and deadlines for implementation were defined. Improvements are monitored in annual internal audits.
2_1_criteria: Through interviews with permanent and temporary employees, it was evidenced that there is no evidence of forced, imposed, forced, trafficked or involuntary labor on the farm. Employees reported that they are free to leave the property after hours, as well as terminate the employment relationship if they wish. There is no retention of documents, salaries or employee benefits. Family members of employees who live on the farm are not required to work on the property. There are no children under 15 working on the farm. There is a Minor Apprentice employee in the role of administrative assistant. Through interviews with employees, it was evident that there was no evidence of discrimination of any kind. The company has different levels for the same functions, with each employee placed in a level according to their level of education. There is also a differentiation by length of service. There is no differentiation between workers of the same level or length of service. Training, benefits and promotion opportunities are provided equally among employees. There is also no evidence of punishment, coercion or aggression of any kind.
2_2_criteria: All workers are registered. There is an Employment Contract binding the company to the employees, with all pertinent information, in writing. Employment contracts include all relevant information and, in addition, workers are informed of working conditions at the time of hiring, as verified in interviews with permanent and temporary employees.
2_3_criteria: Workers demonstrated in interviews knowledge and understanding of issues related to health and safety. Workers health is monitored through periodic medical examinations. There is health and safety training, including specific training on standards NR 6, NR 11, NR 12, NR 20, NR 23, NR 33, NR 35, as well as other training in the area of occupational health and safety and other relevant training. Those responsible for potentially dangerous tasks are properly trained, such as pesticide application, carried out by qualified staff. Health and safety risks are identified and procedures are in place to control them. The Masutti Group has a complete SESMT and has an Occupational Safety Technician and occupational nurse stationed in each unit, and has documentation relevant to occupational health and safety (PGSSTR and LTCAT). The farm provides PPE and the supply is duly recorded using specific forms. The company has a complete and structured SESMT department, with an occupational safety technician and occupational nurse in each unit, responsible for applying and carrying out all surveys relevant to worker safety requirements. The company is implementing the PAE (Emergency Plan) procedure in case of accidents and emergencies. It currently has an Emergency Plan for Responding to Accidents at Work, which is available in announcements at various points on the property. The property has an outpatient clinic, an ambulance and a 24-hour nurse.
2_4_criteria: Through interviews with permanent and temporary employees, it was evidenced that there is complete freedom to join trade union organizations, with some interviewees confirming that they are union members, while others reveal that they did not participate. Terminations of employment contracts are approved by the unions.
2_5_criteria: The minimum remuneration paid on the farm is above the national minimum wage. Verified proof of payment demonstrates that only deductions provided for by law are applied, such as INSS, union contributions and food and health plan deductions, duly agreed between the parties. The working day is 44 hours per week, with occasional overtime, especially during harvest times, which does not exceed 10 hours per week. Hours worked are recorded on a biometric time clock. Workers reported that overtime is voluntary and duly paid, as evidenced by payment slips. Verified through interviews, that workers receive at least one day off for every six days worked. The farm complies with the law in the case of maternity leave. Checked records of a worker on maternity leave at the time of the audit. Housing for farm employees is adequate and has adequate sanitary conditions. Access to drinking water is guaranteed by farms. There are drinking fountains located in several locations. The property has a cafeteria, guided by a nutritionist, serving the 3 main meals of the day to all employees.
3_1_criteria: Sign verified at the entrance to the property containing the telephone contact details. The Masutti Group maintains a page on a social network, as well as having a telephone number available in the regions telephone guides and on the internet. The communication channels are public knowledge.
3_2_criteria: There are no cases of disputes regarding land use rights on the property, as well as there are no adjacent indigenous peoples, nor are there permanent conservation areas, nor schools or any areas of high cultural value close to the farm.
3_3_criteria: There are signs distributed on the property displaying their telephone numbers so that complaints can be made directly. There are also suggestion/complaint boxes in various locations on the property. The farm has the document Procedure for Receiving and Handling Complaints, which determines all procedures in case of receiving complaints. There is also a form to fill out, the Complaint Registration and Handling Form document, which deals with all issues pertinent to complaints and complaints.
3_4_criteria: Job vacancies are advertised through SINE, on the company wall and internal referrals, always looking for workers in the region. The property participates in events and field days. Those responsible participate in lectures and training from the Rural Union, SENAR and companies in the region, as verified in certificates and reports from those responsible. The property purchases products and services from companies in the region.
4_1_criteria: The farm underwent a socio-environmental assessment before being included in the group. A Socio-Environmental Diagnosis was carried out by AlianÃ§a da Terra, which has qualified personnel for such an assessment. The diagnosis is comprehensive and transparent, considering impacts related to the farm.
4_2_criteria: The propertys waste management is governed by the Fazenda Saudades/PaixÃ£o Waste Management Plan. Used batteries are returned in exchange for new ones. Old tires are separated and later collected on the property. The collection of used lubricating oils is carried out by the company Lwart Lubrificantes. Lamps and batteries are stored in a box provided in the propertys workshop and later collected. The houses have septic tanks. Organic waste is buried in a suitable location. A non-conformity was identified in item 4.2.3 as used lubricating oils are stored in suspended tanks without a containment basin. Despite this, the fuel tanks have a containment dam and a fueling lane with a floor, channels and containment box. The machine washing area has a cement floor, gutters and separation box. Oil changes are carried out in a location with a floor, channels and containment box. Recycling is carried out whenever possible. Plastic waste is collected by the company Amazonekos, as well as cans and drums.
4_3_criteria: The use of fossil fuels is recorded when the machines are filled. No increases in fuel use were recorded in the last harvest. The soil matter content is monitored through soil analysis. Soil carbon is increased through practices such as: maintaining straw as ground cover
4_4_criteria: No area expansion was made, as evidenced by satellite image maps comparing the propertys areas in 2008 and 2017.
4_5_criteria: The property map indicates native vegetation, production areas and watercourses. Annual internal audits are carried out to monitor native vegetation. Verified that the farm is restoring degraded areas. The property prohibits any hunting activity within it. Checked warning signs present in the areas. Extractive practices such as collecting native wood or other natural products are also prohibited. The farm has over 10% native vegetation area.
5_1_criteria: The farm adopts good agricultural practices that prevent damage to water bodies, such as: adopting the direct seeding system; straw management for soil cover; use of correctors and fertilizers in accordance with technical recommendations; area maintenance of APP and legal reserve. A non-compliance was identified in indicator 5.1.2 as analyzes are not carried out to monitor water quality. The farm does not use irrigation.
5_2_criteria: The farm identifies the location of watercourses on the map, as well as the status of riparian vegetation. The farm has an area of natural vegetation in the process of regeneration and measures are being taken to recover other degraded areas.
5_3_criteria: Soil quality monitoring is done through soil analysis. Soil quality is preserved through the adoption of practices such as: adoption of the direct planting system; maintenance of straw as soil cover; use of fertilizers and correctives in accordance with technical recommendations; maintenance of APP and legal reserve areas. Erosive processes are prevented through the construction of contour lines, adoption of the direct planting system and maintenance of soil cover. The farm carries out succession of crops. There is no cultivation of soybeans on soybeans, the sanitary void period is respected.
5_4_criteria: The farm has a MIC Â– Integrated Crop Management plan, addressing the use of preventive and control methods that cause less environmental impact . The farm envisages the reduction of potentially harmful agrochemicals in a documented plan. The farm only uses agrochemicals permitted for soybean cultivation and in the dosages prescribed by those responsible, as evidenced in the deposits and records of agrochemical use. A non-conformity was identified in indicator 5.4.5 due to no monitoring records of pests, diseases, weeds and natural enemies.
5_5_criteria: The companys planning sector carries out product purchases. Service orders are opened for the application of pesticides by the technical team in accordance with field monitoring, where the product, quantity, dose, area, plot, weather conditions and team responsible for execution are recorded. Empty packaging is washed at the time of application and then stored in the warehouse. The deposit is covered, closed, locked and marked, but it does not have channels or a containment box, which led to non-compliance in indicator 5.5.2. Empty packaging is delivered to a local receiving center. Pesticides are delivered to the farm by the multinationals that sell them. The place for storing pesticides is covered, locked, closed, marked, has aeration and the packaging is arranged on wooden pallets, but there are no channels or containment box, which led to non-conformity in item 5.5.3. There is an area for preparing pesticides, equipped with a small temporary pesticide deposit, flooring and an ozonizer for equipment decontamination. The preparation of syrup is done using specific equipment for this purpose. Next to the pesticide deposit there is an emergency shower. Used PPE is decontaminated in a laundry dedicated to this purpose. Areas treated with pesticides are demarcated with signposts. Recommendations for the use of improvers and fertilizers are made by agronomists based on the results of soil analyses.
5_6_criteria: The farm does not use any agrochemicals listed in the Stockholm and Rotterdam Conventions. The herbicide Paraquat is used, but it is already planned to gradually reduce its use by 2020.
5_7_criteria: Verified that there is knowledge about the use of biological control agents. There is an intention to use biological nematicides and control agents for defoliating pests, but they have not yet been used.
5_8_criteria: If an outbreak of new pests occurs, farms turn to institutions such as INDEA, MAPA or FundaÃ§Ã£o MT.
5_9_criteria: Measures implemented by the farm to prevent drift include adjusting application equipment, monitoring weather conditions during applications, and maintaining zones free from pesticide application. Aerial applications are carried out at least 1,200 meters from homes and bodies of water. Likewise, the closest populations are notified before applications. Land applications of pesticides respect a minimum distance of 150 meters from homes.
5_10_criteria: The production system adopted by farms is similar to neighboring systems. There are no adjacent areas with sensitive crops, such as organic or conventional agriculture. There are no cases of damage caused by drift to neighboring areas originating from the farm.
5_11_criteria: The farm acquires seeds from legally known sources and also produces seeds, both for its own use and for commercialization. Own seed production is duly approved by APROSMAT, as a way of complying with the intellectual properties of such materials.

Organization: Fundação de Apoio à Pesquisa do Corredor de Exportação Norte ?Irineu Alcides Bays
Name: FAPCEN Grupo III
1_1_criteria: The farms have access to applicable legislation and they are complied with. Employees demonstrated knowledge of legislation and relevant documents were available.
1_2_criteria: Legal rights to use land are defined and demonstrated in documents such as land ownership registrations.
1_3_criteria: The aspects were identified and continuous improvement is being carried out through action plans, showing the companys commitment to meeting all the criteria and indicators of the RTRS standard.
2_1_criteria: Not found evidence of forced, compulsory, slave or involuntary labor during the audit process in work environments or heard during interviews with employees of the audited farms.
2_2_criteria: Own workers receive training and pertinent information about each function to be executed. Indirectly hired workers are instructed on compliance with the labor rights and duties of both parties, where the service provider undertakes to train its employees and provide PPE to perform the work.
2_3_criteria: Information about health and security are documented and are transmitted to employees during Onboarding and during training. Protective equipment is provided according to the risk identified for each function and an action plan is available for emergency situations in production units. All supply points (fuel stations) lack a grounding point for trucks that unload flammable products.
2_4_criteria: Workers are not prevented from having freedom of association and rights to collective bargaining, as well such as the impediment to their presence on farms.
2_5_criteria: Salary remuneration records demonstrate that salaries paid in the company are higher than the national minimum wage, with no salary differences between employees in the same category. Adequate housing provided by the company to employees.
3_1_criteria: Communication occurs through communication channels such as website containing emails telephones, postal address on farm roads with advertising signs written Â“contact usÂ” and via FAPCEN and internally on the scope farms through Â“suggestion and complaint boxÂ”, available near the workers point control.
3_2_criteria: No traditional land users and disputes were found in the assessed area. Property ownership documentation such as registration and lease agreements were presented and are in accordance with applicable legal requirements. Places of importance are identified, maintained and preserved.
3_3_criteria: Complaint channels are available and accessible. Complaints and complaints received are checked and responded to. There were no records of complaints and complaints at the time of the audit.
3_4_criteria: The hired workers come from communities close to the farms and vacancies are advertised through the employees themselves in the local community, where the interested party comes to the company and fill out the job application, I have your resume on file. There are actions that encourage the development of communities close to the scope farms, carried out by the farms and by the Fapcen office.
4_1_criteria: The social, environmental and agricultural aspects were identified for each farm within the certification scope. Studies are available upon request.
4_2_criteria: Storage of waste such as lubricants, batteries, tires and pesticide packaging appropriately. There is an Environmental Management Plan presented during the audit that covers waste management including all areas of the property.
4_3_criteria: The farms promote actions such as fuel registration, fertilization, which is carried out according to soil analyzes and monitored organic matter in the soil.
4_4_criteria: On the Rainha da Serra and Grajau CÃ©res farm it was identified that there was conversion of areas after 2009, on the Granja CÃ©res farm the conversion was located in the biomass (carbon) layer, where it was presented the study that shows that the carbon concentration is less than 88 tons. The Rainha da Serra farm was converted within the permitted period and is not located in a red area on the RTRS map. At Fazenda Carolina do Norte, the "SYNTHETIC REPORT ON LEAF AREA INDEX" was presented. In this study, it was presented that there was no conversion after 2009. however, they all carry out actions to encourage wildlife, protect and restore native vegetation. During the audit it was possible to identify signs signaling preservation and legal reserve areas, as well as the prohibition of hunting in these areas.
4_5_criteria: The farms audited have more than 10% of their area covered by native vegetation, but all of them take steps to encourage wildlife and protect and restore native vegetation. During the audit, it was possible to identify signs marking the preservation and legal reserve areas, as well as the ban on hunting in these areas.
5_1_criteria: The audited farms demonstrate good agricultural practices (erosion control, direct planting, terraces to contain rainwater, drainage channels, adequate application of pesticides and fertilizers, etc.) that help recharge the aquifer and improve quality of surface and underground waters.
5_2_criteria: The vegetation of riparian forests was not removed, FAPCEN presented detailed maps of all farms with indication of riparian vegetation, production areas and watercourses. Such information can also be obtained from the farms' CAR.
5_3_criteria: The farms adopt good agricultural practices, carry out soil analyses, checking the qualities and deficiencies of the soil and correcting them when necessary. Erosion and rotation control techniques of crops are implemented appropriately.
5_4_criteria: Farms use suitable products to control pests and diseases. IPMs and chemical use reduction plans are implemented.
5_5_criteria: Storage and transportation of agrochemicals and dangerous substances within legal requirements. There are signs with product information and re-entry period for recently sprayed areas.
5_6_criteria: Retroactive application records, invoices for purchase and storage of products were checked. None evidence of the use of agrochemicals listed in the Stockholm and Rotterdam Conventions was found. The use of Paraquat was not evidenced on the farms visited within the scope of certification.
5_7_criteria: There is the use of biological control agents on the groups farms.
5_8_criteria: Presented methodology designed to identify and monitor new pests and introduced invasive species, or large outbreaks of existing pests. There were no incidences of new pests that were not identified, according to the records presented.
5_9_criteria: Drift control procedures were presented for the use of agrochemicals near populated areas or bodies of water, as well as other precautions in application of pesticides.
5_10_criteria: All neighboring areas use the same type of production system.
5_11_criteria: The seeds purchased come from legally known sources.
